ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met as a synchronous seminar on Zoom.
Some outdoor meeting.
There was one in-person class day, some assignments were designed to be done outside.
I know students on campus met up to have a socially distant class, but as I am a sophomore, I could not participate.
Combination of live virtual lecture and virtual seminar
Outdoor drawing

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about what art is, and what it means to make it. I also gained a lot of basic drawing skills, like forgetting what things "should" look like and drawing what they actually look like instead.
I learned to see art as more than the representation of light. I developed my skills using multiple media (charcoal, watercolor, etc.), and I learned to study the subjective experience of drawing.
Basic visual and drawing skills, a lot of discussion about shadows, perspective, self-portraiture, "how to see".
I developed a better understanding of drawing and art, and how to incorporate different techniques and ideas into drawing.
A complete change of my artistic approach and the way draw and it improved me for the best
I learned an incredible amount of art skills and broke down any biases about what it meant to create art and be an artist. I learned to gain inspiration from things I love to do.

I learned to think about shadows as independent objects, to draw without a finished product in mind, to draw using one-point perspective, and to draw from observation rather than from a mental concept. I also had a paradigm shift -- I learned that the goal of art is not necessarily to be "correct" or "right," or even "beautiful," but something else entirely. Compelling? Effective? Regardless, it was freeing to stop thinking of art as "right" or "wrong" representation.
Better drawing skills, use of shadows + composition

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a wonderful class. Molly is a wonderful teacher, though the Zoom medium is difficult for any practical drawing class.
Obviously, being online, this course lacked the fluidity that it would have had were it in person. That being said, it was very well designed, kept us all engaged and looking forward to it.
A more explicit assignment schedule, sometimes projects were assigned but not followed through.

I thought this was a great introductory art course. The class environment was good, critiques were helpful, and our discussions were interesting. There could have been more structure at times, but overall I think there was a good balance of flexibility and structure.

I loved this course so much. Molly and Nathaniel are incredible people who will enrich your understanding of art and be ever so patient with your development as an artist, no matter what level you're on. The only weakness is that I never quite knew what the homework was and/or when it was due! The course is a tad unorganized but well worth the scramble.

I always enjoyed the drawing during class, since we were able to get feedback in real time, and the critiques were helpful, especially when Molly or Nathaniel gave us other artists for inspiration. However, I found that the class focused more on abstraction and making meaningful art than learning to observe and represent. Although I came to enjoy that focus, I struggled with it at first, since I had come into the class hoping to learn a concept of drawing I had imagined.
Great professor, really takes time out to explain different techniques and artists who used them

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Molly and Nathaniel often had us draw with our cameras pointed towards our paper, which worked well. I also liked when they gave us outdoor assignments and had us reconvene. The only thing I would have changed is that it might have been nice to have a little more idea what we were going to do ahead of time in a given class.

I thought our discussions over Zoom worked well. It was sometimes challenging to see others' art clearly over Zoom, but this was mainly in cases where we made art during class, so we had not yet uploaded it to the shared class folder and couldn't screen share. The use of a shared Google Drive folder and screen sharing over Zoom allowed for critiques to occur virtually. Overall, I think the class adapted well to the online format.
It worked as well as you can make an art class work over zoom.

The course format was made up of two Zoom classes a week, which we would have had in person had it not been for the pandemic, so I think there is no way to improve on it. Specifically, for our critiques, I really liked that Molly and Nathaniel took the time to make another Zoom room and rotate us in and out of it to dedicate time and privacy to us growing our work.

We could show our art by sharing the screen, and I loved how the virtual medium of the course allowed for an extra layer of artistic experimentation through how we photographed our drawings. We also were able to look at each others' portfolios at any time through Google Drive folders. The lecture slideshows did not always hold my attention and I would have hoped to have a more participatory type of lecture where questions were asked of us, but I also enjoyed learning about each lecture topic.
No problems with zoom learning, we still found ways to engage and show our drawings to each other (zoom webcam during class, google drive folder during critiques)

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Basic Drawing was a gift. The most important thing is not to go in with too many preconceived notions or expectations about what the class will be. Molly has her own way of teaching, and it can seem a little out there or disorganized but you just have to trust it. If you want to learn how to draw really realistically, you should choose a different section. If you want to expand your mind and learn about what makes art beautiful, you should take this one!
Absolutely recommend. Art majors will have to take it, but I also recommend it to the art-curious, or anyone wanting to experiment in drawing and painting in a nurturing environment.
Yes! It's a very great and interactive course for anyone (not just beginners)! But you will only get what you put into this course, expect to put in effort into assignments.
Yes, I think it is a good introductory art course and I enjoyed taking it.
Yes. Any artist should take this class because it will benefit their artistic abilities incredibly.

I would highly recommend this course to another student! It doesn't matter how experienced you are at art. This is the perfect course to develop your skills and understanding of art, whether it's your major or a skill you have always wanted to try.

Yes, I would recommend this course, but be aware that this section is geared towards those who have more intuitive learning styles. It didn't feel like we were formally "taught" a particular way of doing things (besides one-point perspective and basic watercolor technique), but rather we absorbed concepts through trying them out and through comments on our work from Prof. Z-H and Nathaniel. I took the course with a few friends, some of whom enjoyed this way of learning and some of whom felt frustrated. The course is also focused on the aesthetic dimension of art and abstraction. One comment from Prof. Z-H stuck in my head -- something along the lines of "drawing isn't supposed to represent perfectly, since photography took that job -- rather, observational drawing is how you see the world, rather than how the world objectively is." This approach was not what I had expected when I signed up for a class called "Basic Drawing," but I definitely enjoyed the freedom to experiment and be creative.

Yes; the course is geared towards those with differing levels of drawing knowledge / styles such that anyone in the course can improve theirs or get feedback from the instructor / learn from the style of peers
